Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: They develop a floor plan for a new office, ensuring workspaces accommodate employees’ needs efficiently.
Story: My phone buzzes for the third time in ten minutes, my mother’s name lighting up the screen. I know she’s waiting for my daily update—she likes to hear about my day, every detail, and I usually respond right away. But right now, my laptop is open to a half-finished floor plan, and my mind is tangled in the challenge of fitting collaborative spaces and private offices into a limited footprint. My supervisor expects the first draft by tomorrow, and I can’t afford distractions. Still, I picture my mother waiting, maybe worrying if I don’t reply soon. I want to reassure her, to keep up the closeness we’ve always shared, but the lines and measurements on my screen demand my full attention. My fingers hover over the keyboard, torn between typing a quick message and sketching out the next section of the plan. The pressure from both sides tightens in my chest, and I can’t seem to move, caught between being the attentive daughter and the focused architect.
